instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro 2016 Display Replacement, Now no power
threads.message: So I don't usually work on Macbooks, 95 percent of my business is cell phones, but I do the occasional macbook pro display replacement. I was working on my customers <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro 2016 Display Replacement, and now I can't get the device to boot up after putting on the new screen. I'm pretty novice when it comes to diagnosing problems on the macbooks. I did watch some of Rossmanns videos, and checked the voltage with the battery unplugged and got 20 volts. I put on the old screen and still nothing. Can you all help me out here?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro 2016 Display Replacement, Now no power
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Disconnect internal LCD and check external video.
You can also check for USB activity.
Do you get voltage on some big coils?

Did you disconnect the battery before starting to work on the board?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro 2016 Display Replacement, Now no power
threads.message:
I did disconnect the battery 

I donâ€™t know how to check voltage on big coils. With my electrometer?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro 2016 Display Replacement, Now no power
threads.message:
Very bad to work on the board with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> present  :(...

Use DC voltmeter scale to check voltage.
